column5: is a fortified complex in the center of Moscow
column6: overlooking the Moskva River to the south
column7: Saint Basil's Cathedral and Red Square to the east
column8: and the Alexander Garden to the west. It is the best known of the kremlins (Russian citadels)
column11: and the enclosing Kremlin Wall with Kremlin towers. In addition
column12: within this complex is the Grand Kremlin Palace that was formerly the Tsar's Moscow residence. The complex now serves as the official residence of the President of the Russian Federation and as a museum with 2

column15: and is often also used metonymically to refer to the government of the Russian Federation in a similar sense to how "White House" refers to the Executive Office of the President of the United States. It previously referred to the government of the Soviet Union (1922–1991) and its highest members (such as general secretaries
column19: and commissars). The term "Kremlinology" refers to the study of Soviet and Russian politics.

column5: and the exposition of Russian wooden sculpture and carvings.

column1: == History ==
=== Origin ===
The site had been continuously inhabited by Finno-Ugric peoples since the 2nd century BC. The Slavs occupied the south-western portion of Borovitsky Hill as early as the 11th century
column2: as evidenced by a metropolitan seal from the 1090s which was unearthed by Soviet archaeologists in the area. The Vyatichi built a fortified structure (or "grad") on the hill where the Neglinnaya River flowed into the Moskva River.

column1: Up to the 14th century
column2: the site was known as the 'grad of Moscow'. The word "Kremlin" was first recorded in 1331 (though etymologist Max Vasmer mentions an earlier appearance in 1320). The grad was greatly extended by Prince Yuri Dolgorukiy in 1156
column3: destroyed by the Mongols in 1237 and rebuilt in oak in 1339.

column1: === Seat of grand dukes ===

Dmitri Donskoi replaced the oak walls with a strong citadel of white limestone in 1366–1368 on the basic foundations of the current walls; this fortification withstood a siege by Khan Tokhtamysh. Dmitri's son Vasily I resumed construction of churches and cloisters in the Kremlin. The newly built Cathedral of the Annunciation was painted by Theophanes the Greek
column2: Andrei Rublev
column3: and Prokhor in 1406. The Chudov Monastery was founded by Dmitri's tutor

column1: === Residence of the tsars ===
Grand Prince Ivan III organised the reconstruction of the Kremlin
column2: inviting a number of skilled architects from Renaissance Italy
column3: including Petrus Antonius Solarius
column4: who designed the new Kremlin wall and its towers
column5: and Marcus Ruffus who designed the new palace for the prince. It was during his reign that three extant cathedrals of the Kremlin
column7: and the Palace of Facets were constructed. The highest building of the city and Muscovite Russia was the Ivan the Great Bell Tower
column8: built in 1505–08 and augmented to its present height in 1600. The Kremlin walls as they now appear were built between 1485 and 1495. Spasskie gates of the wall still bear a dedication in Latin praising Petrus Antonius Solarius for the design.

column1: After construction of the new kremlin walls and churches was complete
column2: the monarch decreed that no structures should be built in the immediate vicinity of the citadel. The Kremlin was separated from the walled merchant town (Kitay-gorod) by a 30-meter-wide moat
column3: over which Saint Basil's Cathedral was constructed during the reign of Ivan the Terrible. The same tsar also renovated some of his grandfather's palaces
column4: added a new palace and cathedral for his sons
column5: and endowed the Trinity metochion inside the Kremlin. The metochion was administrated by the Trinity Monastery
column6: and contained the graceful tower church of St. Sergius
column7: which was described by foreigners as one of the finest in the country.

column1: During the Time of Troubles
column2: the Kremlin was held by the Polish forces for two years
column3: between 21 September 1610 and 26 October 1612. The Kremlin's liberation by the volunteer army of prince Dmitry Pozharsky and Kuzma Minin paved the way for the election of Mikhail Romanov as the new tsar. During his reign and that of his son Alexis and grandson Feodor
column7: Amusement Palace and the palace of Patriarch Nikon were built. Following the death of Alexis's son
column10: Tsar Peter escaped with much difficulty from the Kremlin and as a result developed a dislike for it. Three decades later
column11: Peter abandoned the residence of his forefathers for his new capital

column1: === Imperial period ===
Although still used for coronation ceremonies
column2: the Kremlin was abandoned and neglected until 1773
column3: when Catherine the Great engaged Vasili Bazhenov to build her new residence there. Bazhenov produced a bombastic Neoclassical design on a heroic scale
column4: which involved the demolition of several churches and palaces
column5: as well as a portion of the Kremlin wall. After the preparations were over
column6: construction was delayed due to lack of funds. Several years later the architect Matvey Kazakov supervised the reconstruction of the dismantled sections of the wall and of some structures of the Chudov Monastery
column7: and built the spacious and luxurious Offices of the Senate
column8: since adapted for use as the principal workplace of the President of Russia.

column1: During the Imperial period
column2: from the early 18th and until the late 19th century
column3: the Kremlin walls were traditionally painted white
column4: in accordance with fashion.French forces occupied the Kremlin from 2 September to 11 October 1812
column5: following the French invasion of Russia. When Napoleon retreated from Moscow
column6: he ordered the whole Kremlin to be blown up. The Kremlin Arsenal
column7: several portions of the Kremlin Wall and several wall towers were destroyed by explosions and the Faceted Chamber and other churches were damaged by fire. Explosions continued for three days
column10: and the damage was less severe than intended. Restoration works were undertaken in 1816–1819
column11: supervised by Osip Bove. During the remainder of the reign of Alexander I
column12: several ancient structures were renovated in a fanciful neo-Gothic style
column14: including all the buildings of the Trinity metochion
column15: were condemned as "disused" or "dilapidated" and were torn down.

column1: On visiting Moscow for his coronation festivities
column2: Czar Nicholas I was not satisfied with the Grand Palace (alias Winter Palace)
column3: which had been erected in the 1750s to the design of Francesco Rastrelli. The elaborate Baroque structure was demolished
column4: as was the nearby church of St. John the Precursor
column5: built by Aloisio the New in 1508 in place of the first church constructed in Moscow. The architect Konstantin Thon was commissioned to replace them with the Grand Kremlin Palace
column6: which was to rival the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg in its dimensions and in the opulence of its interiors. The palace was constructed in 1839–1849
column7: followed by the re-building of the Kremlin Armoury in 1851.

column1: After 1851 the Kremlin changed little until the Russian Revolution of 1917; the only new features added during this period were the Monument to Alexander II and a stone cross marking the spot where in 1905 Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia was assassinated by Ivan Kalyayev. These monuments were destroyed by the Bolsheviks in 1918.
=== Soviet period and beyond ===

The Soviet government moved from Petrograd to Moscow on 12 March 1918. Vladimir Lenin selected the Kremlin Senate as his residence. Joseph Stalin also had his personal rooms in the Kremlin. He was eager to remove all the "relics of the tsarist regime" from his headquarters. Golden eagles on the towers were replaced by shining Kremlin stars
column2: while the wall near Lenin's Mausoleum was turned into the Kremlin Wall Necropolis.

column1: The Chudov Monastery and Ascension Convent
column2: with their 16th-century cathedrals
column3: were dismantled to make room for the military school. The Little Nicholas Palace and the old Saviour Cathedral were pulled down as well. The residence of the Soviet government was closed to tourists until 1955. It was not until the Khrushchev Thaw that the Kremlin was reopened to foreign visitors. The Kremlin Museums were established in 1961
column4: and the complex was among the first Soviet patrimonies inscribed on the World Heritage List in 1990.

column1: Although the current director of the Kremlin Museums
column2: Elena Gagarina (Yuri Gagarin's daughter) advocates a full-scale restoration of the destroyed cloisters
column3: recent developments have been confined to expensive restoration of the original interiors of the Grand Kremlin Palace
column4: which were altered during Stalin's rule.

column1: ==== State Kremlin Palace ====
The State Kremlin Palace (alias Kremlin Palace of Congresses)
column2: was commissioned by Nikita Khrushchev as a modern arena for Communist Party meetings
column3: and was built within the Kremlin walls 1959–1961. Externally the palace is faced with white marble and the windows are tinted and reflective. The construction of a large modern public building in a historic neighborhood generated an uproar
column4: especially since the building replaced several heritage buildings including the old neo-classical building of the State Armory and some of the rear parts of the Great Kremlin Palace. Although this was not the first time that the Soviet government had destroyed architectural heritage (notably the Chudov Monastery and Ascension Cloisters) in the Kremlin and in the country in general
column5: by the mid 1950s laws were in place effectively considering all pre-Soviet constructions as historical monuments and preventing their demolition
column6: in some ways making the construction illegal. Nevertheless
column7: the Palace was integrated into the larger complex of the Great Kremlin Palace with walkways linking it to the Patriarchal Chambers and the Terem Palace.

column1: == Buildings ==
The existing Kremlin walls and towers were built by Italian masters from 1485 to 1495. The irregular triangle of the Kremlin wall encloses an area of 275
column2: 000 square metres (2
column4: 000 sq ft). Its overall length is 2
column7: but the height ranges from 5 to 19 metres (16 to 62 ft)
column8: depending on the terrain. The wall's thickness is between 3.5 and 6.5 metres (11 and 21 ft).

column1: Originally there were eighteen Kremlin towers
column2: but their number increased to twenty in the 17th century. All but three of the towers are square in plan. The highest tower is the Troitskaya
column3: which was built up to its present height of 80 metres (260 ft) in 1495. Most towers were originally crowned with wooden tents; the extant brick tents with strips of colored tiles go back to the 1680s.

column1: Cathedral Square is the heart of the Kremlin. It is surrounded by six buildings
column2: including three cathedrals. The Cathedral of the Dormition was completed in 1479 to be the main church of Moscow and where all the Tsars were crowned. The massive limestone façade
column3: capped with its five golden cupolas
column4: was the design of Aristotele Fioravanti. Several important metropolitans and patriarchs are buried there
column5: including Peter and Makarii. The gilded
column6: three-domed Cathedral of the Annunciation was completed next in 1489
column7: only to be reconstructed to a nine-domed design a century later. On the south-east of the square is the much larger Cathedral of the Archangel Michael (1508)
column8: where almost all the Muscovite monarchs from Ivan Kalita to Ivan V of Russia are interred. (Boris Godunov was originally buried there
column9: but was moved to the Trinity Monastery.)

column1: There are two domestic churches of the Metropolitans and Patriarchs of Moscow
column2: the Church of the Twelve Apostles (1653–1656) and the exquisite one-domed Church of the Deposition of the Virgin's Robe
column3: built by Pskov artisans from 1484–1488 and featuring superb icons and frescoes from 1627 and 1644.

column1: The other notable structure is the Ivan the Great Bell Tower on the north-east corner of the square
column2: which is said to mark the exact centre of Moscow and resemble a burning candle. Completed in 1600
column3: it is 81 metres (266 feet) high. Until the Russian Revolution
column4: it was the tallest structure in the city
column5: as construction of buildings taller than that was forbidden. Its 21 bells would sound the alarm if any enemy was approaching. The upper part of the structure was destroyed by the French during the Napoleonic Invasion and has been rebuilt. The Tsar bell
column6: the largest bell in the world
column7: stands on a pedestal next to the tower.

column1: The oldest secular structure still standing is Ivan III's Palace of Facets (1491)
column2: which holds the imperial thrones. The next oldest is the first home of the royal family
column3: the Terem Palace. The original Terem Palace was also commissioned by Ivan III
column4: but most of the existing palace was built in the 17th century. The Terem Palace and the Palace of Facets are linked by the Grand Kremlin Palace. This was commissioned by Nicholas I in 1838. The largest structure in the Kremlin
column5: it cost an exorbitant sum of eleven million rubles to build and more than one billion dollars to renovate in the 1990s. It contains dazzling reception halls
column8: and the lower storey of the Resurrection of Lazarus church (1393)
column9: which is the oldest extant structure in the Kremlin and the whole of Moscow.

column1: The northern corner of the Kremlin is occupied by the Arsenal
column2: which was originally built for Peter the Great in 1701. The southwestern section of the Kremlin holds the Armoury building. Built in 1851 to a Renaissance Revival design
column3: it is currently a museum housing Russian state Regalia and Diamond Fund.

column1: The haloalkaliphilic methylotrophic bacterium Methylophaga murata was first isolated from deteriorating marble in the Kremlin.
=== Helipad ===
In order to stop the disruptions to Moscow traffic caused by motorcades
column2: President Vladimir Putin authorized the construction of the Kremlin helipad. The helipad was completed in May 2013. The President will now commute back and forth to the Kremlin using a Mil Mi-8 helicopter. Careful consideration was taken in choosing the location of the helipad; the location chosen is said to be of no threat to the architecture of the Kremlin.
